Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: The supervisor has asked you to move a stack of unused materials to a different storage area sometime before the end of the day.
Story: I watched my stepbrother, Jamie, eyeing the battered ramp at the edge of the lot, skateboard in hand. He grinned at me, his helmet askew, and shouted, “Watch this!” My heart thudded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But I was also on the clock, sweat already soaking my shirt from hauling bricks all morning. My supervisor had just told me to move a heavy stack of unused tiles to the far side of the site before the end of the day. If I didn’t get started now, I’d be behind, and I couldn’t afford another warning. Jamie’s foot hovered over the board, ready to launch down the steep, uneven ramp. I could see the loose gravel, the jagged edge. If I left him alone, he could get hurt. But if I stayed, I’d be shirking my job. My hands clenched, torn between the weight of responsibility for my brother and the pressure to keep my job. I stood frozen, caught between two worlds, as Jamie called my name again.
